author: @bestShortsyt763
text: The while loop can also be useful for algorithms that will repeat an unknown number of times, such as factoring a number. Correct me if I'm wrong, but I would say calling them "interchangeable" with a for loop might be a little misleading. 'for' statements iterate over the elements of a sequence or iterable object whereas a while loop only executes if a condition is true.  In C++ they are virtually interchangeable, but not so in Python, I think.

text: i am a beginner coder and i have a simple calculator program and when i run it and i get an answer it stops running. how do i get it to run again?  here is my code: def calc() :   operator = input("Choose an operator: ")   if operator == "addition":     add = int(input("Choose your first number: "))     add2 = int(input("Choose your second number: "))     print ("Answer:",add + add2)   elif operator == "subtraction":     sub = int(input("Choose your first number: "))     sub2 = int(input("Choose your second number: "))     print ("Answer:",sub - sub2)   elif operator == "multiplication":     mult = int(input("Choose your first number: "))     mult2 = int(input("Choose your second number: "))     print ("Answer:",mult * mult2)   elif operator == "division":     div = int(input("Choose your first number: "))     div2 = int(input("Choose your second number: "))     print ("Answer:",div / div2)   elif operator == "remainder":     mod = int(input("Choose your first number: "))     mod2 = int(input("Choose your second number: "))     print ("Answer:",mod % mod2) calc()

author: @hachij_
text: simple program for you guys :)  # adding number until while break  sumNum = 0 userNumber = int(input('Enter your number: (or -1 to quit)\n'))  while True:  sumNum += userNumber  userNumber = int(input('Enter your number: (or -1 to quit)\n'))  if userNumber != -1:   continue  else:   break  print('loop break after user enter \'-1\' ') print(f'Result: {sumNum}')

text: # Here is a counter i made for anyone that may need it.  import time # Allows you to play with time in python.  my_number = int(input("")) # Let you input a number  number_counting_up = 0 # Give number_counting_up the value of 0  def rerun_counter (): # Define rerun_counter: Â  Â  counter () Â  Â  Â  Â # Run the modul called counter  def counter (): Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  # Define counter Â  Â  if Â number_counting_up >= my_number - 1: Â  Â  Â  Â  Â # If number_counting_up is MORE THAN OR EQUAL TO my_number -1 (-1 means that number but with 1 taken away from it) Â  Â  Â  Â  print ("It has been", my_number , "seconds!") # Print it has been (How ever many seconds you inputed) seconds. Â  Â  Â  Â  quit () Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  # Quit the Application Â  Â Â  Â  Â  elif number_counting_up != my_number: # Or if number_counting_up is NOT EQUAL TO my_number: Â  Â  Â  Â  number_counting_up += 1 Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  # Add 1 to number_counting_up Â  Â  Â  Â  global number_counting_up Â  Â  Â  Â  # Make number_counting_up a global command (So it can be used outside of the if statement) Â  Â  Â  Â  print (number_counting_up) Â  Â  Â  Â # Print the number that number_counting_up is currently on Â  Â  Â  Â  time.sleep (1) Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â # Wait a second Â  Â  Â  Â  rerun_counter () Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â # Run the program called rerun_counter  counter () # This makes the if statement called counter run.      # Sentdex videos = 100 out of 10
